By MARC DUVOISIN
The Flying Monkey Concert
Series now in its second year of
existence, has planned a full
schedule of musical

community during the Spring
semester.
The concerts, which take place
on the Hopkins campus, are open
to Baltirriore-area residents as
well as students.
Mitch Clarvit, the director of

introduce Baltimore-area bands

"Hopkins bands are equally
welcome as are community
audiences. We provide publicity

musicians themselves in order

of their reputations," he
continued.
"I suppose you could say that
our chief objective is to provide
the Hopkins community with

high-quality, original music for
free, or at a very reasonable
price. The music can be of any
variety - classical, folk or rock,
electric or acoustic. The only
requirement is that the bands
play original compositions during
some part of their show," he
added.

the Student Council and allows
free admission for virtually all
the concerts. "We make a deal

another one free."

A team is only as good as its
players; but the players can only
be as good as their coaches make
them. .Beginning like a coach's
nightmare, the Johns Hopkins
University basketball season
seemed to be off to a bad start.
Losing four of their first five
games, the Blue Jays looked to
their coaches for a reason and a
solution to the problem.
Unlike any previous Hopkins
basketball team, this year's squad
has two coaches, head coach
Gary Rupert and assistant coach
James "Snuffy" Smith. After
many hours of deliberation, the
two attacked the problem and
devised a solution. The quality of
their solution is proven by the
fact that the Jays have since won
eight of their last nine games.
Gary Rupert 'tame to Johns
hlopkins three seasons ago. Last
year he obtained a 14-10 record,
the best in Hopkins basketball
history. A graduate of
Bloomsburg State College in
Pennsylvania, Rupert lettered in
football, basketball and baseball.

second leading punter in the
nation among small colleges with
a 47-yard per kick average. In
basketball, Rupert won All-NA IA
and All-State honors as a guard.

school in Philadelphia and began
his coaching career as an assistant
coach at Philadelphia Textile.

the 1970 NCAA college division
championship. In the same year.
Gary received his masters degree

in education from Temple
University.
Since 1970

athletic department in the fall of
1970. He has been the head
coach of the Blue Jay basketball
team ever since and also coaches
the receivers of the football
team.

most important additions to
Hopkins basketball is that of
James Smith, better known as
Snuffy. Snuffy graduated from
Baltimore University and
commenced his coaching career
there as an assistant basketball
coach. He followed his head
coach to Wheeling, West Virginia,
where they both continued in the
same coaching capacities as
before. Snuffy, however, also
served as Assistant Director of
Admissions at Wheeling College.
Snuffy
Snuffy joined the Hopkins
coaching staff on the request of
Coach Rupert, who had known
Snuffy at B.U. and became aware
of his desire to return to the
Baltimore area. The new assistant
is also presently working at the
Stella Mans Hospice, where he is
program director for a pilot
project of his own design dealing
with the remotivation and
resocialization of geriatric
patients. His work is focused
around 44 patients whose average
age is 85 years old.
Mrs. Emily Crockett, director
of programs and activities at the
Hospice claims, "The patients
like Snuffy very much. He relates

f

well and has alot of empathy for
that age group."
Coach Rupert describes Snuffy
as "aggressive" and an "excellent
teacher of the game." "He wants
to be a varsity coach some day
and he'll be a good college
coach," declared Rupert.
Positive
Smith likes the Hopkins
athletic program and terms the
staff as "positive." His greatest
admiration for Hopkins athletics
seem to be, as he put it,
"Hopkins consists of student
athletes and not athletic
students." He sees a good balance
between athletics and academics
here.
"There are very few good
coaches in the Baltimore area"
says Smith, who considers
Rupert to be one of them. "He
knows his priorities and is a very
sound coach. He gives me some
responsibilities and respects my
opinions. He makes me feel like I
am a contribution to the team."
Duo
A better duo of coaches would
be hard to find anywhere. Rupert
and Smith are like right and left
hand gloves, and between the
two of them any problem can be
ironed out. Rupert believes that
with two coaches more attention
can be given to players which
means they can get more out of
their practices.
It can readily, be seen that
both Rupert and Smith are
fanatics about the sport of
basketball and with that kind of
double attitude it has to rub off
onto the players.

"I don't mean to imply that intersession is bad," said

minimester.

R. Suskind to bring up the matter of intersession now,

killed proposals to end intersession twice and to attempt a
run around the Assembly by forcing a vote in the CUS
appears to be nothing but a political ploy. It is to be hoped
that the CUS will give the program a strong vote of
confidence and that no further attempts to scuttle it will
be made.

Spotlight on basketball coaches
By CHUCK SLONIM
A team is only as good as its
players; but the players can only
be as good as their coaches make
them. .Beginning like a coach's
nightmare, the Johns Hopkins
University basketball season
seemed to be off to a bad start.
Losing four of their first five
games, the Blue Jays looked to
their coaches for a reason and a
solution to the problem.
Unlike any previous Hopkins
basketball team, this year's squad
has two coaches, head coach
Gary Rupert and assistant coach
James "Snuffy" Smith. After
many hours of deliberation, the
two attacked the problem and
devised a solution. The quality of
their solution is proven by the
fact that the Jays have since won
eight of their last nine games.
Gary Rupert 'tame to Johns
hlopkins three seasons ago. Last
year he obtained a 14-10 record,
the best in Hopkins basketball
history. A graduate of
Bloomsburg State College in
Pennsylvania, Rupert lettered in
football, basketball and baseball.
During his senior year, he was the
second leading punter in the
nation among small colleges with
a 47-yard per kick average. In
basketball, Rupert won All-NA IA
and All-State honors as a guard.
Gary started teaching grade
school in Philadelphia and began
his coaching career as an assistant
coach at Philadelphia Textile.
While he was there. Textile won
the 1970 NCAA college division
championship. In the same year.
Gary received his masters degree

in education from Temple
University.
Since 1970
Rupert joined the Hopkins
athletic department in the fall of
1970. He has been the head
coach of the Blue Jay basketball
team ever since and also coaches
the receivers of the football
team.
What seems to be one of the
most important additions to
Hopkins basketball is that of
James Smith, better known as
Snuffy. Snuffy graduated from
Baltimore University and
commenced his coaching career
there as an assistant basketball
coach. He followed his head
coach to Wheeling, West Virginia,
where they both continued in the
same coaching capacities as
before. Snuffy, however, also
served as Assistant Director of
Admissions at Wheeling College.
Snuffy
Snuffy joined the Hopkins
coaching staff on the request of
Coach Rupert, who had known
Snuffy at B.U. and became aware
of his desire to return to the
Baltimore area. The new assistant
is also presently working at the
Stella Mans Hospice, where he is
program director for a pilot
project of his own design dealing
with the remotivation and
resocialization of geriatric
patients. His work is focused
around 44 patients whose average
age is 85 years old.
Mrs. Emily Crockett, director
of programs and activities at the
Hospice claims, "The patients
like Snuffy very much. He relates

f

well and has alot of empathy for
that age group."
Coach Rupert describes Snuffy
as "aggressive" and an "excellent
teacher of the game." "He wants
to be a varsity coach some day
and he'll be a good college
coach," declared Rupert.
Positive
Smith likes the Hopkins
athletic program and terms the
staff as "positive." His greatest
admiration for Hopkins athletics
seem to be, as he put it,
"Hopkins consists of student
athletes and not athletic
students." He sees a good balance
between athletics and academics
here.
"There are very few good
coaches in the Baltimore area"
says Smith, who considers
Rupert to be one of them. "He
knows his priorities and is a very
sound coach. He gives me some
responsibilities and respects my
opinions. He makes me feel like I
am a contribution to the team."
Duo
A better duo of coaches would
be hard to find anywhere. Rupert
and Smith are like right and left
hand gloves, and between the
two of them any problem can be
ironed out. Rupert believes that
with two coaches more attention
can be given to players which
means they can get more out of
their practices.
It can readily, be seen that
both Rupert and Smith are
fanatics about the sport of
basketball and with that kind of
double attitude it has to rub off
onto the players.
